It's more Half-Life. It's not as good as Opposing Force and certainly not as long, but it's pretty fun - except for some infuriating parts where they throw you at some puzzles with ridiculous solutions.

Near the end of the game, there's a door that needs to be blown up with TNT, but the cables that connect the TNT to the detonator were cut. So, the logical solution would be to shoot the TNT so it would blow up, or use a grenade, right? Nope. You have to get a BARREL and push it in the middle of the disconnected cable, so the BARREL "connects" them? What? That doesn't even make sense, that is the stupidest solution I've ever seen to a puzzle, ever. What were they thinking? The only reason why I wasn't stuck in this part for a long time is because I've just finished the two previous Half-Life games, so I'm used to sh*t like this, so when I see it I immediately know it's time to open youtube and search for the solution. On the walkthorugh video that I saw, EVERY single comment is talking about how stupid this "puzzle" is.

Overall, the game is pretty fun and immersive, and a fine addition to the Half-Life story from a different perspective, but I just had to express how frustrating that part was.

While Blue Shift doesn't offer anything fundamentally different from Half-Life, it is certainly interesting seeing the events of the Black Mesa Incident from a different perspective. As Barney Calhoun, your mission is to escape to safety from the Black Mesa Research Facility as it is besieged by aliens that invaded the facility in the immediate aftermath of the disastrous Resonance Cascade while you also face the challenge of the HECU tasked with containing the incident and silencing all witnesses. 
If you had played the original Half-Life title, the gameplay and mechanics will be all too familiar (in a good way) as you have much of the same weaponry, enemies and puzzles to deal with. However, you should set your expectations on this being more of an expansion pack from a story line standpoint as you don't use new weapons or encounter new enemies, which is understandable as you are playing in the same time frame you would have with Gordon Freeman the first few hours of Half-Life.
I would definitely recommend this though I base that recommendation on buying a Half-Life bundle as Blue Shift is relatively short since a reasonably competent player can complete it in just over 4 hours.

Na jego drodze staną zarówno obce formy życia, powstałe w wyniku nieudanych, przeprowadzonych w laboratorium badań, jak również oddziały wojska przybyłe na miejsce, aby eksterminować resztę zarażonych ludzi. [h1] ROZGRYWA [/h1]
Jeśli chodzi o gameplay jest to właściwie to samo co pierwsza część czyli: "pod względem mechaniki Half-Life wprowadził całą masę nowatorskich elementów, które przez długie lata wyznaczały kierunek rozwoju gier z gatunku FPS. W stosunku do większości dynamicznych strzelanek z tego okresu produkcja firmy Valve zaskakuje m.in. rozbudowaną i wolno zawiązującą się warstwą fabularną. Przykładowo, już na samym początku gry przez dłuższy czas spotykamy przyjaźnie nastawione postaci, nie mając ani do kogo, ani z czego strzelać. Zamiast znanych z większości podobnych gier przerywników filmowych, w Half-Life istotne elementy fabuły przekazywane są w formie oskryptowanych sekwencji stworzonych na silniku gry.|


[h1] AUDIO & GRAFIKA [/h1]

[h1] PS. [/h1]

[u]Half Life: Blue Shift[/u] is one of the spin-offs of the most popular videogame [u]Half Life[/u].

Set in the same period in which Gordon Freeman becomes a Black Mesa scientist, you will enter the role of the famous Half Life 2 character, [u]Barney Calhoun[/u], who, in this case, will appear as a young member, just hired, of Security in Black Mesa and will have to flee the terrifying hell unleashed by aliens invading Black Mesa and the inhuman massacre of the American military forces that are chasing Gordon Freeman.
With the help of the survivors, he will have to overcome all sorts of obstacles and save the scientists of Black Mesa.

The game was made with the same mechanics as the original Half Life, but you will have fewer weapons available than Half Life and Half Life: Opposing Force and the story is very short (here are the flaws of this game) but it is equally interesting, since you will play, watching from a different point of view, that of a common young officer who immediately finds himself having great responsibilities (therefore Gordon Freeman does not necessarily have to be the hero who saves everyone and does great deeds).
Barney, like Gordon, will prove to be an important character who has made a huge contribution to save the world and members of Black Mesa.

I recommend you to play this game because it represents one of the important pieces of the Half Life story.

So, you have already played “Half-Life (Source)” and the expansion pack “Opposing Force” but still haven’t got enough of the Black Mesa experience? Well, here comes another add-on with a story from the same timeline, this time following erstwhile side character, full-time Black Mesa security guard and part-time conspiracy theorist Barney Calhoun through all the events that should probably be quite familiar to veteran players by this point. Considering how preposterous the angle of this expansion is, it’s almost annoying how much fun it is to return to Black Mesa one more time. “Blue Shift” is quite short, but entertaining enough, especially in instances where the story intersects with that of the original “Half-Life.”
